Heterogeneous immobilized lipase catalysts have been widely used in packed-bed reactors (PBR) in industry. This reactor configuration provides an environment with low shear forces, allows the catalyst to be easily recovered and reused, and continuously removes products and substrates not consumed by the reaction. This reduces inhibition of enzymatic activity and enables greater operational stability. This review aims to conduct a technical-scientific evaluation of the use of PBR with immobilized lipase catalysts. Therefore, the state-of-the-art was conducted by selecting articles published between 2019 and 2024. They were analyzed and discussed innovatively, focusing not only on the production methodologies of these enzymatic catalysts but also on the characteristics that make them suitable for the flow reactor, immobilization methods, reactor configurations, operational limitations, and process intensification techniques. The use of immobilized lipase catalysts in PBR is mainly limited by external mass transfer phenomena, which are among the most important topics discussed. This review could significantly contribute to advancing research into reactions catalyzed by lipases. These catalysts usually present high efficiency, specificity, selectivity, biocompatibility, and, sometimes, biodegradability [2–4]. The immobilization of enzymes on solid supports or insoluble cross-linked aggregates is necessary because soluble enzymes generally have low stability under process conditions and are difficult to recover and reuse, which may result in high production costs [3,5–8]. Nevertheless, choosing the right biocatalyst is crucial for the process to occur efficiently, with practical implications for industrial applications. Ideally, the support should be mechanically stable, inert to the enzyme, biologically compatible, resistant to degradation by microorganisms, commercially available, and economically viable [9]. In addition, other factors influence the efficiency of heterogeneous enzymatic catalysts in processes, such as the shape and size of the particles, porosity and pore size, composition, and the type of interaction involved in immobilization [10]. However, the efficiency of processes involving enzymatic reactions does not depend exclusively on the supports used to produce heterogeneous biocatalysts but also on the configuration of the designed reactors and reaction systems [8,11,12]. The main types of reactors used in these processes are stirred tank reactors, packed-bed reactors, and fluidized bed reactors, which allow for adapting different configurations and operating modes [13,14]. Enzymatic catalysis is generally carried out in reactors that operate in batch mode. However, continuous operation has several advantages [12,15]. Reactors operating in continuous flow mode present economic benefits due to greater efficiency in controlling reaction parameters and reagent mixing, lower shear force applied to immobilized enzymes, greater capacity for reuse of enzyme catalysts, and greater energy efficiency, resulting in greater productivity [16]. Different operating modes can significantly influence enzymatic processes' efficiency, selectivity, and yield. Enzymatic synthesis is often sensitive to pH, temperature, substrate, and product concentrations. Continuous mode, for example, can be advantageous for maintaining constant reaction conditions, while fed-batch mode can be useful for controlling substrate addition and avoiding product inhibition [17,18]. Many studies investigate and compare compounds' enzymatic synthesis in different operation modes [19–22]. Guajardo et al. [19] investigated the use of deep eutectic solvents (DES) in lipase-catalyzed esterification processes. Different reactor configurations were tested, including batch, fed-batch, and continuous packed-bed modes. The fed-batch operation mode was superior to the traditional batch mode, achieving a 90 % conversion rate with a substrate flow rate of 0.01 mL min-1, representing a 59 % increase in conversion compared to the batch mode. In the continuous mode using a packed-bed reactor, a 67 % conversion rate was observed after seven cycles, demonstrating the potential for reusing the reaction medium. In addition, the stability of the biocatalyst was remarkable in this operation mode, with only a 2 % decrease in activity over ten days. It was observed that although the reactors operated in fed-batch and continuous modes presented similar productivity, the continuous packed-bed system offered greater stability of the immobilized lipase catalyst, making it attractive for long-term operations. Thus, using low-viscosity DES mixtures in processes catalyzed by immobilized lipase in continuous systems was effective, achieving high conversion rates and allowing greater catalyst stability. The choice of operating mode can significantly affect production costs and process scalability. Continuous modes, for example, are often easier to scale up for industrial production and can be more economical regarding enzyme and substrate usage [23,24]. The packed-bed reactor is among the most reported types of reactors for continuous flow enzymatic catalysis (illustrated in Fig. 1 ). This type of reactor consists of a bed formed by catalysts compacted in a column, through which the flow containing the substrate is pumped [25]. This system promotes the continuous removal of products and substrate not consumed by the reaction, reducing the inhibition of enzymatic activity, improving the number of total enzyme renewals, and, consequently, the reaction rates [26,27]. The packed-bed reactor is the most used in continuous reactions with immobilized lipases [25]. Packed-bed reactors are widely regarded as the optimal choice for reactions involving immobilized lipases, offering a range of benefits that enhance efficiency and cost-effectiveness [28,29]. Their design supports a high enzyme loading, which maximizes catalytic activity, while the continuous-flow operation ensures economical and scalable production suitable for industrial applications [12]. Moreover, immobilized lipases in these reactors demonstrate significantly improved stability, extending their operational lifespan. The fixed positioning of the enzyme minimizes losses and simplifies product separation by eliminating the need for additional processing steps, further streamlining the overall process [12,30,31]. Packed-bed reactors also precisely control key parameters such as temperature, pH, and substrate concentration, maintaining ideal reaction conditions. Their scalability and ability to reuse immobilized enzymes across multiple cycles further reduce operational costs and enhance feasibility for large-scale applications. The continuous-flow setup additionally facilitates rapid product removal, minimizing inhibitory effects. At the same time, their versatility accommodates various lipases and support materials, making them adaptable to a wide range of reaction requirements [29,32–35]. These advantages collectively explain the extensive use of packed-bed reactors in industrial biotechnology and biocatalysis, where performance, practicality, and economic viability are critical [8,31,36–40]. In recent years, immobilized lipase catalysts in packed-bed reactors have been extensively investigated to adapt the process to an industrial scale [8]. However, experimental research has primarily focused on laboratory-scale reactors. Few studies have explored the scale-up of processes catalyzed by immobilized lipases in packed-bed reactors (PBR). One example is the work of Zhang et al. [41]. The authors investigated the synthesis of medium- and long-chain triacylglycerols (MLCT) through interesterification. They used a pilot-scale reactor with a bed volume of approximately 1360 L and 783.0 g of packed Lipozyme TL IM. The study reported a product containing 76.61 wt% MLCT. Additionally, it demonstrated the high operational stability of the biocatalyst, which achieved 25 cycles without significant loss of enzymatic activity. These lipases (glycerol ester hydrolases, EC 3.1.1.3) have the biological function of catalyzing the hydrolysis of ester bonds in triglycerides, producing free fatty acids and glycerol [42–45]. However, they are known for their broad specificity and affinity for various substrates, allowing their use in various reactions, including esterification, acidolysis, interesterification, transesterification, and aminolysis, in addition to other promiscuous reactions [45–49]. Lipases have characteristics that allow stability in organic media and high specificity for long-chain fatty acids [42–44]. Several authors have published reviews discussing the production, use, and market prospects for immobilized enzyme catalysts [1,50–62], some explicitly addressing lipases [12,63–70]. Remonatto et al. [12] explores the state-of-the-art industrial applications of immobilized lipases in different reactor systems and seeks to identify the main factors that affect the application of immobilized lipases and configurations of the most common reactor types. Eskandari et al. [64] reviewed the advances and perspectives of microbial lipases, highlighting their specificity and efficiency. Microbial lipases are those produced by fungi, bacteria, and yeasts, and they are becoming commercially favorable due to the ease of production in large quantities. The authors address these enzymes' traditional and modern purification methods and their applications in food, detergents, biodiesel, and bioremediation, among other sectors. The discussion focused on the types of reactions catalyzed by these lipases in free and immobilized form and the products that can be achieved. Bansode et al. [69] and Dias et al. [70] present in their reviews discussions on the intensification methods of lipase-catalyzed processes, such as the application of ultrasonic irradiation and the use of supercritical CO2. These are comprehensive reviews on aspects of the application of these methods and the parameters that influence their efficiency, addressing free and immobilized lipases in different reactor configurations. Aiming to contribute to the scientific debate and the advancement of enzymatic reactions in continuous mode, we propose this review article. Unlike the approaches discussed in other literature reviews, this work aims to delve into a technical-scientific evaluation of enzymatic catalysis in different packed-bed reactor configurations with immobilized lipases. Therefore, we seek to discuss the production methods and operational aspects that make immobilized lipase catalysts suitable for this type of reactor. In addition, different packed-bed reactor configurations, operational limitations, and process intensification techniques are also discussed. Finally, possible future directions for this line of research are explored. 2 Methods This review was based on a bibliographical search developed through two large scientific databases, Scopus and Web of Science. Initially, a broad search was performed using the following terms and Boolean operators: lipase AND (fixed OR packed) AND bed, searching within Article title, Abstract, and Keywords. In Scopus, this search identified 516 documents, while in Web of Science, it returned 665 documents. The search was then refined by applying the following filters: year (2019 – 2024), document type (article), and language (English). After applying these filters, the results were reduced to 89 publications from Scopus and 141 from Web of Science. Each document was manually reviewed to confirm its relevance regarding immobilized lipase catalysts in packed bed reactors. Only studies that provided experimental results and advances in biocatalyst production, reactor configuration, or process intensification techniques were included. Studies that did not directly impact packed bed reactors were excluded. This careful screening led to the final selection of 77 publications. Therefore, the contributions and advances of using immobilized lipase catalysts in packed bed reactors are discussed below. 3 Immobilized lipase biocatalysts for packed-bed reactors and applications Due to the low stability of soluble enzymes when subjected to process conditions and the high cost attributed to their recovery and reuse, the immobilization of enzymes on solid supports or the formation of insoluble cross-linked aggregates have been widely studied [3,5–8,10]. However, it is common for the properties of enzymes to change due to the type of interaction that enables their immobilization, the type of material to which they are being supported, or even the quantity of enzymes supplied to this support [67]. It is essential to carefully evaluate the type of material, the immobilization technique, and the interactions that occur in the formation of the biocatalyst so that the process occurs efficiently [71,72]. The immobilization process is possible through physical and (or) chemical interactions between enzymes and the surface of materials chosen as support, entrapment within the support matrix during their synthesis, or chemical cross-linking between clusters of enzymes mediated by a binding agent [73]. Fig. 2 illustrates the main enzyme immobilization methods. The production of immobilized lipase catalysts and their application in packed-bed reactors are reported in different fields, such as structured lipid synthesis [74], oil hydrolysis [75], biodiesel production [76], and lubricant production [77]. The enzymatic activity of the catalyst resulting from the immobilization process is proportionally related to the amount of immobilized enzyme, in addition to the porosity and surface area of the chosen support [10]. The presence of pores in supports plays a crucial role in enzyme immobilization, allowing for a greater surface area and, consequently, more enzyme retention [78]. Moreover, the support material directly influences the functional properties and efficiency of the catalytic system. Firstly, the choice of support determines how the enzyme will be immobilized through covalent bonding, adsorption, entrapment, or encapsulation, which impacts both structural stability and catalytic activity. Well-designed support can also enhance the reusability of the biocatalyst by facilitating separation from the reaction medium and ensuring that the enzyme maintains its activity over multiple cycles [79–81]. This is particularly crucial for industrial applications, where stability and cost-effectiveness are key factors. Lastly, the economic feasibility of the support material must also be considered, as affordable and durable materials make the biocatalyst production process more competitive [82–84]. However, diffusional limitations must be considered since it is more difficult for the enzymes to penetrate into the pores of the support, and they may remain in the outer layers during this process [78]. Large structures such as enzymes have mass transfer rates and adsorption capacity reduced when the supports have small pore sizes [85]. This effect reduces the immobilization efficiency, defined as the percentage of enzyme successfully attached to the support. It also decreases catalytic activity, as enzymes tend to accumulate in the outer layers of the support. To minimize these issues, materials with larger surface areas or more prominent pores are often used. However, this strategy can weaken the interaction between enzyme and support, increasing the risk of enzyme leaching [37,86–88]. Reducing the size of solid particles used to support enzyme retention is a common strategy to reduce diffusional effects, as they reduce the boundary layer on the material's surface and, consequently, improve mass transfer between the fluid part and the solid [37,86]. However, there is a need for caution in size adjustment, as there is a limit between the size adjustment and the benefits obtained. In bed reactors, the smaller the size of the packaged particles, the greater the pressure drops in the system, reducing its process efficiency [10,78]. In immobilization by covalent binding, in which enzymes are chemically bound to the support, diffusion is influenced by the accessibility of the functional groups on the support and the pore size [72,89–91]. This technique offers more excellent stability and less possibility of leaching, but diffusional limitations can impact catalytic efficiency, mainly when internal pores restrict access of the substrate to the enzyme. In addition, structural changes in the enzyme during the binding process can block access to the active site, further reducing efficiency [72,89–91]. Encapsulation, in turn, creates additional physical barriers to mass transfer. Enzymes encapsulated in polymeric matrices or gels depend on the diffusion of substrates and products through the matrix, the efficiency of which is determined by properties such as thickness, density, and pore size. Although this technique protects the enzyme from adverse environmental conditions, diffusion barriers can limit the reaction rate and compromise the performance of the biocatalyst [81,92–95]. In the case of cross-linked aggregates (CLEA), diffusion limitations tend to be lower since solid supports impose no physical barriers. Nevertheless, the size of the enzyme aggregates can affect mass transfer, making it necessary to optimize the process, for example, by reducing the size of the aggregates to improve diffusion. This technique offers the advantage of eliminating solid supports, reducing potential barriers to diffusion [96–98]. Biocatalysts produced by these different techniques are applied in packed-bed reactors [75,96,99,100]. The technique used and the support material's characteristics significantly influence performance parameters, such as conversion, yield, and productivity. They are impacted by porosity, particle size, and bed distribution [79,101]. The bed architecture directly affects mass transfer, the residence time of the reagents, and the access of substrates to the catalytic sites of the enzymes. The porosity of the bed, defined by the proportion of space between the particles, is a determining factor. A bed with low porosity can generate regions with restricted flow or even dead zones where mass transfer is limited, reducing the efficiency of the reaction. On the other hand, very high porosity can reduce the contact time between the reagents and the enzymes, negatively affecting conversion and yield [88,102–105]. Another important aspect is the uniformity of the bed distribution. The formation of preferential flow channels, often caused by uneven packing, can result in inefficient use of biocatalysts and reduced conversion rates, as part of the bed remains underutilized [106]. To mitigate this problem, controlled packing techniques or the inclusion of structuring elements (e.g., glass beads) in the bed can be employed [8,76,96]. The bed configuration also influences reactor productivity. Well-designed beds maximize the residence time of reactants under ideal conditions, optimizing the interaction between substrate and enzyme and increasing both conversion and process yield. Therefore, the performance of a packed bed reactor depends on a careful balance between the physical properties of the bed, such as porosity and particle size, and the operating conditions, such as flow rate and pressure. Optimizing these parameters is essential to maximize catalytic efficiency and meet the demands of large-scale industrial applications [39,107–112]. The immobilization techniques applied and the type of material used are directly related to the costs of producing immobilized enzyme catalysts and their performance in processes [36]. It is crucial to understand the significance of enzyme conformation and the effects of immobilization on it within the context of biocatalysis. Inadequate immobilization techniques can significantly impact their catalytic activity and even lead to enzyme inactivation, resulting in an immobilized enzyme with compromised thermal and mechanical stability [38]. Commonly, immobilization techniques do not allow this effective control, causing changes in their conformation and in the refolding of proteins, which can hinder the access of substrates to active sites and cause a decrease in their catalytic activity or irreversible inactivation [34]. When dealing specifically with the immobilization of lipases, the influence of the interfacial activation mechanism is added. Interfacial activation of lipases is a phenomenon where the enzyme undergoes structural changes in response to interaction with hydrophobic interfaces, such as hydrophobic supports [113–115]. Based on the presence of a mobile polypeptide chain often associated with a lid, this mechanism isolates its active site from the reaction medium in the absence of a hydrophobic interface (closed form) [114,116–118]. This conformation is thought to be stabilized by intramolecular interactions, which reduce the accessibility of the catalytic triad—comprising serine, histidine, and aspartate or glutamate residues—to substrates [113,114,116,117]. When the lipase encounters a hydrophobic interface, such as a hydrophobic support material, the interaction induces a conformational change in the enzyme. This involves the movement of the lid away from the active site, exposing the catalytic triad [63,117,119]. The hydrophobic nature of the interface mimics the lipid-water interface, a natural environment where lipases are activated during substrate binding. This structural rearrangement enhances substrate accessibility, facilitating the binding of hydrophobic substrates to the active site. In this state, the serine residue of the triad becomes available to perform a nucleophilic attack on the ester bond of the substrate. In contrast, the histidine and aspartate/glutamate residues stabilize the transition state and assist in proton transfer [113–116]. Interfacial activation is thus crucial for optimizing the performance of lipases in various applications, especially in industrial processes involving immobilized enzymes on hydrophobic supports. The ability of hydrophobic supports to induce and stabilize the open conformation of lipases highlights their importance in biocatalysis, where maximizing enzyme activity and reusability is essential [63,101,118–124]. There is no simple approach in the literature that defines the best immobilization method for enzymes, making experimental characterization an essential tool to guide the decision-making process. It is a well-established fact that the mass transfer between substrates and immobilized enzymes plays a crucial role in determining the apparent rate of the reaction [109,125–127]. The immobilization process can impose restrictions on the flow and mobility of enzymes and solutes, leading to a decrease in the efficiency of the catalytic process when compared to reaction systems with soluble enzymes [104]. The potential of adjusting and optimizing auxiliary mass transfer conditions to overcome these challenges is promising, but further research is needed to fully understand and exploit this potential [34]. Given the limitations, the operator of processes involving immobilized enzyme catalysts must consider the essential characteristics of the material chosen as immobilization support. Regarding the support, the expected characteristics are mechanical stability, biological compatibility, resistance to degradation by microorganisms, commercial availability, and economic viability [9]. Other characteristics that describe heterogeneous enzymatic catalysts and influence their efficiency in processes are the shape and size of the particles, porosity and pore size, chemical composition of the material, and the type of interaction involved for immobilization to occur [10]. The bibliographic evaluation conducted in this research showed that 55.4 % of innovative research works developed in the last five years used commercially available immobilized lipase catalysts. Novozym® 435 and Lipozyme® TL IM were found to be the most common. The other works proposed the preparation of innovative catalysts or utilize those developed in previous research in packed-bed reactors. Below are some fundamental aspects the authors consider when choosing catalysts applied in packed-bed reactors. 3.1 Commercial immobilized lipase catalysts 3.1.1 Novozym® 435 Novozym® 435 is the commercially available immobilized lipase catalyst most used in industrial applications and the most reported in research on lipase activity in packed-bed reactors (34.9 %), being marketed by Novozymes, a multinational company in the biotechnology sector [128,129]. It is formed by immobilizing Candida Antarctica B lipase (CALB), an enzyme produced from recombinant strains of Aspergillus niger, in Lewatit® VP OC 1600. It is ion-exchange resin produced by LANXESS, a global chemical company [129–131]. According to the manufacturer, Lewatit® VP OC 1600 is designed for applications that require high adsorption capacity and excellent mechanical resistance. Lewatit® VP OC 1600 does not have functional groups. Its structure is based on a polymethacrylate-divinylbenzene copolymer [132]. The Novozym® 435 catalyst has properties such as spherical shape, particle size in the range between 0.3 and 0.9 mm, density of approximately 430 kg m-3, surface area of 130 m2 g-1, average pore diameter of 15 nm, classifying it as meso or macroporous depending on the author, and water content between 1 and 2 % [112]. Considered to be a non-specific and thermostable enzyme with an optimum temperature range between 30 and 60 °C and an optimum pH between 5 and 9, having esters and alcohols as specific substrates, it presents an activity of 1000 PLU g-1 (PLU = Propyl Laurate Unit), where 1 PLU is the amount of enzymatic activity that generates 1 µmol of propyl laurate per minute under defined standard conditions [42,131,133]. This information describes many actions, which justifies its wide application in industrial reactions. The described properties make Novozym® 435 suitable for use in packed-bed reactors. Abd Razak et al. [112], investigated the synthesis of glycerol dioleate ester in a bed microreactor with packed Novozym® 435 and the limitations of mass transfer at moderate temperature (45 °C), with the aim of determining the reaction rate control factor. The authors observed that increasing the flow reduces the resistance in the boundary layer and reduces the estimated value for the Damköhler number (Da), keeping the value below 1 for all flow rates tested. Therefore, the overall rate of esterification of oleic acid with glycerol falls into the reaction-limited regime, indicating that the diffusion effect dominates as the rate-limiting step in substrate conversion. After confirming that at the evaluated flow rates, the external mass transfer effects were insignificant and could be eliminated, the values of the Thiele modulus (Φ) and the internal efficiency factor (ηI) achieved showed that intraparticle diffusion is insignificant. Therefore, under the given process conditions, both substrates are not limited by internal mass transfer effects, implying reaction kinetics as the limiting factor [112]. Abd Razak et al. [112] also hypothesized that excess oleic acid substrate contributes to reducing diffusion limitation effects, as the support to which CALB is immobilized (Lewatit® VP OC 1600) is hydrophobic. Therefore, an excess amount of oleic acid, which is nonpolar for the most part, is required to achieve high reaction conversion. Lower concentrations of oleic acid added to excess water lead to an incomplete esterification reaction. It is necessary to find out about the water content around the enzyme, as there is an ideal level of water to maintain the conformation and functionality of the enzymes. Excess water in the reaction medium can cause the formation of a hydration layer on the enzyme, reducing stability and its catalytic activity in esterification reactions [134]. Furthermore, excess water can alter the polarity of the solvent and the solubility of substrates and products, causing limitations in mass transfer processes and conversion yields [70]. Reports indicate a partial or total loss of catalytic activity of Novozym® 435 when in contact with short-chain alcohols, probably due to conformational changes [135–138]. It is known that the matrix that supports CALB undergoes changes in contact with many organic solvents and ionic liquids and can even form substances capable of becoming acyl donors in esterification and transesterification reactions [135,139]. The effect on catalytic activity and pore structure due to immersion of Novozym® 435 in organic solvents for 24 h was reported [130]. In response, it was observed that even the most common organic solvents significantly affected the pore structure of the catalyst. The solvents butanol, acetonitrile, and ethyl acetate caused significant changes in the mesopores, the latter being able almost to double the volume of the macropores, resulting in a restructuring of the matrix and marked swelling. The factors affecting Novozym® 435 during operation, including temperature, pH, and ionic strength, should not be underestimated. If not carefully managed, these factors can lead to significant fluctuations that directly influence the weak interactions governing enzyme immobilization by adsorption. This can result in enzyme leakage from the matrix, thereby reducing its catalytic activity. For instance, several studies highlight the operational stability of Novozym® 435, maintaining its catalytic activity for up to 10 reaction cycles [112,140–143]. All these factors must be considered when choosing the catalyst, with particular emphasis on the maintenance of its activity and the stipulation of an appropriate reaction environment. 3.1.2 Lipozyme® TL IM The Lipozyme® TL IM catalyst is the second most reported immobilized lipase catalyst (23.8 %) applied to packed-bed reactors in the last five years. It is a commercial product formed by the immobilization of lipase obtained from the thermophilic fungus Thermomyces lanuginosus, which is produced by submerged fermentation of a genetically modified microorganism (Aspergillus oryzae) in cationic and hydrophilic silica gel granules through anion exchange, containing particle sizes varying between 0.3 and 1 mm [105,144–147]. The optimal process parameters are pH between 6 and 8 and temperature between 50 and 75 °C [148]. The information provided about Lipozyme® TL IM does not mention the existence or size of pores. Lipozyme® TL IM presents sn-1,3 regiospecificity and it has esters as a specific substrate, with activity of 250 IUN g-1 (IUN = Interesterification Unit). 1 IUN corresponds to the amount of enzymatic activity that produces 1 µmol of tritractable butyric acid from the substrate glycerol tributyrate per minute under defined standard conditions [144,148,149]. Despite being widely used in experimental tests, less characterization and process parameters information is available for Lipozyme® TL IM compared to Novozym® 435. The structure of Thermomyces lanuginosus lipase is well defined, and it has an active site covered by a catalytic triad formed by three amino acid residues: “Ser (146) – His (258) – Asp (201)”, located at points relatively distant from each other in the peptide chain. However, they become strategically close to the active center due to the folding of this chain. This triad of amino acids is protected in the molecule by a hydrophobic polypeptide chain (residues 86–93) that results in a large lid, which can completely isolate the active center from the reaction medium in its closed form. Interacting with the lipid/water interface triggers the interfacial activation mechanism, undergoing a conformational change and exposing the active site [63,101,118–124,150]. Lipozyme® TL IM presents low mechanical resistance when subjected to agitation due to the action of shear forces, and, due to this, it is common for it to suffer a reduction in its catalytic activity caused mainly by the desorption of the enzyme on the support. This effect makes it unsuitable for stirred tank reactors as it reduces its potential for reuse in batch processes and its operation in continuous mode [151]. The external mass transfer model for the hydrolysis of palm olein was validated using Lipozyme® TL IM as a catalyst in a recirculated packed-bed batch reactor. Therefore, the homogenization of the substrate occurs in a magnetically stirred tank that feeds the column where the catalyst is packaged, with the output connected to the tank, forming a closed circuit [105]. External mass transfer limitations refer to effects that occur outside the catalyst's surface but affect the reaction's overall rate. With this investigation, the researchers found that the increase in the flow rate improved the mass transfer between the medium containing the substrates and the enzymes because the turbulence of the flow reduces the thickness of the film present on the surface of the catalyst, which exerts resistance to the transfer of external mass, improving diffusion. As a result, the mass transfer coefficient and the reaction rate constant were observed with the increase in flow. Therefore, given the conditions provided for the tests, external mass transfer limitations affect the overall reaction rate for the hydrolysis of palm olein in a packed-bed reactor with Lipozyme® TL IM [105]. Regarding operational stability, Lipozyme® TL IM was used in a rotating reactor to synthesize 2-ethylhexyl palmitate in cycles with a reaction time of 1 h, comparing the same reaction in a continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR) [152]. Under the optimal process conditions, around 70 % conversion was achieved in the CSTR, reaching a less than 50 % value after the ninth reaction cycle. On the other hand, the packed-bed proved stable, with a conversion of approximately 99 % during nine reaction cycles, requiring fifteen cycles to reach a yield of less than 80 %. The authors attribute the better performance of the packed-bed reactor to the reduction of mechanical action due to the absence of agitation and the less damage suffered due to the polar substrate, protecting the catalyst from the protein desorption effect [140–143,152]. Researchers investigated the synthesis of low-calorie structured triacylglycerols produced by acidolysis of olive pomace oil with medium-chain fatty acids or interesterification with their ethyl ester forms. The process was conducted in a packed-bed reactor with immobilized lipase as catalysts, including Lipozyme® TL IM, and operated in continuous mode [153]. Deactivation was only observed when Lipozyme® TL IM was in the presence of a medium-chain fatty acid containing ten carbons, presenting a linear deactivation model and a half-life of 228 h. No catalyst deactivation was recorded during the time evaluated when in contact with fatty acid containing eight carbons and its ethyl ester forms. Zhang et al. [154] evaluated changes in the morphology of the Lipozyme® TL IM surface, using a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope, when used in the enzymatic interesterification of palm olein in a packed-bed reactor operated in continuous mode. The authors compared samples of three types: fresh biocatalyst, after 80 min of reaction; and after 100 h of reaction. A small change in its surface was reported, preserving almost all of its concentration and adsorbed protein, reducing from 0.48 to 0.46 mg g-1. In contradiction, a significant reduction in its enzymatic activity was reported, going from 236 to 65 U. Using infrared and fluorescence spectroscopy, the authors observed a gradual increase in the fluorescence intensity of lipase as it lost its catalytic activity. This could result from the prolonged reaction time or the number of cycles, destroying some bonds responsible for maintaining the spatial structure of the enzyme. Changes in the secondary and tertiary structures of the protein exposed the internal groups, causing a decrease in the catalytic activity of the lipase during the reaction in continuous mode. Lipozyme® TL IM showed operational stability and high productivity when applied in packed-bed reactors operated in continuous or batch mode, justifying its wide application and predilection among researchers of catalytic bioprocesses involving immobilized lipases. However, new materials for application, such as immobilization support and biocatalyst production techniques, are still being investigated. Therefore, innovative research works developed in the last five years that resulted in new immobilized lipase catalysts or their first application in packed-bed reactors is discussed here. 3.2 Innovation in immobilized lipase catalysts The immobilization of enzymes on supports can be carried out using different techniques, but the general objective is always the same [64]. The fixation of enzymes on supports aims to improve the stability of their three-dimensional structure at contact organic solvents, at greater temperatures and pH ranges, and other denaturing agents, in addition to allowing easy recovery in biocatalytic processes [64,155]. It is common for industrial processes to occur under adverse conditions, which leads to the inactivation of enzymes and, consequently, the loss of catalytic activity, harming their industrial use [98]. Different types of support can be used to immobilize lipases. For use in packed-bed reactors, it is common to use inorganic materials (e.g., silica and clays), organic materials (polymeric resins and cellulose), and hybrid materials (combining characteristics of inorganic and organic materials). Some characteristics are fundamental for the suitability of these materials as supports for enzyme immobilization, such as mechanical stability, compatibility with the enzyme and the substrate, and the ability to prevent enzyme leaching during the process. The choice of immobilization support directly influences the activity and stability of the enzyme [95,101,156]. Immobilization methods can be classified according to their reversibility [62,80,157,158]. Table 1 summarizes innovative research into developing immobilized lipase catalysts applied in packed-bed reactors over the past five years. 3.2.1 Reversible immobilization techniques Reversible methods attach the enzyme to the support through weak, non-covalent interactions, such as ionic bonds, hydrophobic interactions, and specific affinity. These interactions allow easy removal and recovery of the protein, reuse of the support, and lower risk of deactivating the enzyme's catalytic activity during the immobilization process. However, some disadvantages are noted, such as the possibility of protein loss during use and lower stability when compared to irreversible methods [79,178]. The reversible adsorption method produced the enzymatic catalysts Novozym® 435, and Lipozyme® TL IM discussed previously. In addition, several works have investigated the production and application of immobilized lipase catalysts by reversible methods in packed-bed reactors [22,74,77,145,160,167,172]. Lipase immobilization by adsorption stands out among the reversible methods, being the oldest and simplest. Lipase binds to solid supports through weak bonds such as van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonds, and hydrophobic bonds. This technique prevents the enzyme structure from being compromised after being immobilized, allowing the preservation of its activity. The weak interactions between the protein and the solid surface allow its desorption, also known as enzyme leakage. This leakage is disadvantageous to the process, causing loss of enzymatic activity and contamination of the reaction product by dispersed enzymes [67,79,157,178]. Packed-bed reactors favor catalysts produced by the adsorption technique due to the absence of shear forces. However, enzyme leakage may still occur under certain operating conditions due to the weak nature of the enzyme-support interactions [12,179]. Hydrophobic supports are frequently used in the immobilization of lipases due to the expected hyperactivation caused by the interfacial activation mechanism. The study conducted by Vilas Bôas et al. [22] involved immobilizing various lipase source in Diaion™ HP-20 resin, a nonpolar styrene-divinylbenzene copolymer, to synthesize biolubricant esters. This was achieved through the direct esterification of fusel oil with oleic acid in a continuous packed-bed reactor. The researchers identified that all enzymatic catalysts formed had high adsorption efficiency and hydrolytic activity, reaching 4128 U g-1. The catalysts with immobilized lipases from R. oryzae and P. camemberti stood out regarding the esterification reaction for producing isoamyl oleate, with ester productivity of 1000 µmol g-1 min-1. In continuous mode, the ester productivity was 65 times greater than in batch reactions. However, the enzymatic catalyst used showed low operational stability mainly due to the retention of water formed by the reaction, shifting the reaction equilibrium and accelerating protein desorption. The authors proposed a series system, where molecular sieves were packed in a column after the reaction and before a second bed packed with the enzymatic catalyst. This allowed greater productivity and a longer steady state and increased the half-life of 59.3 h to 179.6 h. In another study [82], different commercial resins (Lewatit® VP OC 1064 MD pH, Amberlite™ XAD™ 1180, Purolite® Lifetech™ ECR 1090M e Purolite® Lifetech™ ECR 8806M) were tested for the immobilization of Lipozyme® CALB L lipase by adsorption interaction. For this, the resins were packed in a bed, and the enzymatic extract was permeated through the column. Subsequently, the packed-bed was used for the enzymatic synthesis of cetyl esters. Except for Lewatit, the supports tested demonstrated an immobilization efficiency of approximately 70 %. The increase in temperature favored the action of all catalysts derived from immobilization in the esterification reaction, with no thermal deactivation phenomena being identified during the period evaluated. Amberlite recorded a 10.5 % increase in substrate conversion after the temperature rose from 60 to 70 °C and 12.4 % when the temperature reached 80 °C. The authors attributed this result to the effect of temperature on the kinetic constant, the evaporation of water generated during the synthesis of esters, and the decrease in viscosity of the reaction medium. After 15 reaction cycles for 1 h at 70 °C and a flow rate of 54 L h-1, only the catalysts formed by the immobilization of lipase in the Amberlite and ECR 8806M resins were able to maintain their initial catalytic activity, the catalysts formed by the resins ECR 1090M and Lewatit maintained their activity for only 3 and 5 cycles, respectively. Finally, the authors evaluated the processes economically, concluding that the Amberlite and ECR 8806M catalysts were the lowest-cost immobilized derivatives due to the maintenance of their catalytic activity during a more significant number of reaction cycles [82]. 3.2.2 Irreversible immobilization techniques In contrast, irreversible methods bind the enzyme to the support permanently through covalent interactions or permanent encapsulation, such as: covalent bonding, where the enzyme is chemically linked to the support through covalent reactions with functional groups on the support, such as amino, carboxyl, or thiol groups; by cross-linking, where cross-linking agents are used to forming covalent bonds between enzymes and between the enzyme and the support; and by entrapment in polymeric matrices, which occurs by incorporating the enzyme within structures formed by synthetic or natural polymers, permanently immobilizing it [84,89,90]. Immobilization by irreversible methods can be advantageous as it promotes high stability of the enzyme on the support, low probability of leaching, and resistance to changes in process conditions [180]. However, the enzyme is subject to partial deactivation due to structural changes caused by covalent bonds, in addition to there being no possibility of recovering the protein and reusing the support [83]. The most common technique to make immobilization irreversible is to promote covalent bonds, mainly aiming to improve conformational stability and thermostability [181]. These bonds can occur due to the insertion of functional groups on the surface of the support, promoting cross-linking after physical adsorption or through multiple covalent chains, making the enzyme structure rigid and fixed [84,90,178,182]. As a result, there are catalysts with greater stability at extreme pH and high temperatures in the presence of organic solvents. However, the strong interactions in immobilization can cause distortions in the enzyme structure and cause its partial or complete inactivation [83,183]. A lipase with high tolerance to saline environments (Bacillus cereus) was immobilized on a nanoporous activated carbon support functionalized with ethylenediamine and glutaraldehyde. Soon after that, they were packaged in a bed reactor to eliminate fatty substances in highly saline wastewater and increase the biodegradability of tannery effluents [174]. The authors observed that each gram of support could immobilize 210 units of lipase, with its retention capacity favored by the increase in the salinity of the suspension medium. The model that best described this immobilization process was the Freundlich isotherm, suggesting the formation of multiple layers due to physical interactions between the support matrix and the lipase tolerant to high salt concentrations. When subjected to continuous regime in a packed-bed reactor, the catalyst maintained high operational stability and maximum catalytic activity (10 days). Fat degradation was best represented by the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, indicating a limiting dependence on the concentration of fat present in the medium. A grease removal efficiency above 99 % was achieved by integrating the enzymatic reactor into a biological reactor containing anoxic and oxic zones [174]. In Fernández-Penas et al. [96], reinforced cross-linked lipase crystals were produced on a preparative scale, packed in a column, and applied to the continuous hydrolysis of 4-nitrophenyl butyrate. The effective activity of the crystals remained approximately one order of magnitude lower when compared to their free form, which was expected due to diffusional effects. However, the authors indicated that considering normalizing the initial and final masses of the crystals, the activity maintained a retention of approximately 100 % after ten reaction cycles. In a medium containing an organic solvent, ten times more catalyst mass was required to achieve hydrolysis with approximate conversion, in addition to low thermal stability, being completely deactivated after 24 h at 60 °C. In a packed-bed operated in a closed circuit, it was possible to reach a maximum conversion of 65 % of the substrate after 16.7 h at a flow rate of 0.25 mL min–1 [96]. These reactors are formed by a chamber filled with compacted catalysts resembling a bed. Its operation consists of a flow containing the substrates that feed the reaction being permeated by this bed, with length, width, and height varying according to the type of operation performed [40,187,188]. It describes the reactor configurations, bed characteristics, process parameters, and the results obtained. Then, some of these works are discussed. It is observed that there is a gap in providing information on process configuration and parameters and in the evaluation of mass transfer effects and productivity results. Most researchers do not consider the packing quality and the effects of mass transfer constraints. Unlike stirred tank reactors, the catalyst suffers low shear forces, preserving the structural characteristics of the immobilized enzyme, increasing reaction efficiency and operational stability, reducing production costs, and allowing the operation to occur in continuous mode [154,164,189]. The success of heterogeneous enzymatic catalysis depends not only on the quality of the immobilization process but also on the reactor configuration and the operating conditions used [199,200]. In the previous topic, the characteristics of immobilized enzyme catalysts that influence the operation of the packed-bed reactor were discussed. Next, design aspects that have been the target of investigation by researchers in processes catalyzed by lipases will be discussed. The packed-bed reactor can be easily scaled up, and this is the result of characteristics such as lower energy consumption when compared to other reactor models, the high enzymatic load provided for the reaction, the low volume, high efficiency in substrate conversion, easy catalyst reuse, and relatively simple process control instrumentation [130,194]. Furthermore, the operating mode of the packed-bed reactor allows products to be continuously removed from the column, facilitating subsequent purification processes [33,164]. However, irregular packing can result in inhomogeneous flows and the formation of the channeling phenomenon (Fig. 3 ), affecting the overall performance of the reactor [201]. Channelization occurs when flow flows through preferential paths, such as cracks in the bed or gaps between the bed and the wall [202]. The external mass transfer rate is negatively affected due to uneven bed packing [40]. Residence time distribution (RTD) analysis can assess bed packing quality. In these systems, reactant flow through the packed bed is influenced by several factors, including bed porosity, packing uniformity, and interactions between the fluid phase and immobilized biocatalysts. RTD analysis provides a detailed characterization of how reactants move through the reactor, providing a profile of flow dynamics that identifies potential deviations from ideal plug flow behavior and the extent of mixing within the system [106,203–205]. This information is essential for diagnosing reactor performance, as deviations from ideal flow patterns, such as channeling, bypassing, or dead zones, can significantly impact enzymatic reaction efficiency. For example, channeling reduces effective contact between substrates and immobilized enzymes, leading to suboptimal conversion rates, while dead zones can result in localized substrate stagnation and uneven reaction progress [106,203–206]. RTD analysis is particularly valuable for scaling up enzymatic PBR from laboratory to industrial scale. As reactor dimensions increase, hydrodynamic behavior becomes more complex, potentially exacerbating non-idealities such as axial dispersion and flow maldistribution. By incorporating RTD studies into the design and operation phases, it is possible to mitigate these effects, ensuring that the reactor configuration is aligned with the desired process outcomes. Additionally, RTD data can guide the selection of operating conditions, such as flow rates and bed packing strategies, to improve process stability and reproducibility [106,203–206]. Vilas Bôas et al. [165] used the RTD methodology to characterize the hydrodynamic behavior of the packed bed reactor used for the continuous production of monoacylglycerol via glycerolysis of babassu oil by immobilized Burkholderia cepacia lipase. After the RTD analysis, they calculated the mean residence time equal to 34.33 min for a reactor with a volume of 10 cm3, suggesting axial dispersion within the PBR. Therefore, the axial dispersion model for a closed vessel was considered the most appropriate to explain the system, with a low mass transfer coefficient being reported. Furthermore, it is known that on the particle's surface, the fluid has a velocity equal to zero, resulting in the formation of a film of stagnant fluid called the boundary layer, which attributes resistance to mass transfer between the fluid and the external surface of the particle. The boundary layer thickness (δ), and therefore the value of the transfer resistance attributed to it, is affected by the fluid's physical, chemical, and hydrodynamic properties and particle size [106,207,208]. Fig. 4 illustrates the interaction between the fluid flow and the particles inside a packed bed reactor, highlighting the δ that forms around the particles. The boundary layer thickness is a crucial factor in reactor performance, as it regulates the mass transfer between the fluid and the catalytic surface. Flow velocity has a direct influence on the boundary layer thickness. At higher flow velocity conditions, the velocity gradient in the fluid adjacent to the particle intensifies, which reduces δ. This is due to increased shear forces at the fluid boundary, resulting in more efficient convective transport. Thus, reducing δ promotes a higher mass transfer rate, decreasing diffusive limitations at the surface of the catalytic particle. In contrast, lower flow velocities increase δ, reducing the mass transfer efficiency and negatively impacting the reaction kinetics [106,207,208]. In addition, particle size also plays a significant role. Smaller particles have a higher surface-to-volume ratio, potentially increasing the specific contact area for catalytic reactions. However, smaller particles can result in greater bed compaction, increasing flow resistance and influencing boundary layer formation. If this size is reduced excessively, it will cause a pressure drop. The fluid velocity influences the boundary layer, and its increase during operation favors mass transfer. However, the high back pressure puts the safety of the process at risk [106,130,207,209]. Fig. 4 demonstrates that doubling the particle size changes the flow pattern. Larger particles generate thicker boundary layers due to the greater separation between the fast-moving fluid and the catalytic surface, which can lead to more pronounced diffusive limitations. At fixed velocities, larger particles enhance the diffusion effect, while smaller particles, at higher velocities, optimize mass transfer. This balance is crucial for PBR reactor design. It ensures the flow is fast enough to minimize mass transfer limitations but not so fast as to cause preferential channels or bed instability [106,130,207,209]. The use of glass spheres has been reported in scientific methodologies as an effective way of constructing beds with adequate packaging, allowing very small diameter particles to be used and working with the desired flow rates without a pressure drop or high back pressure [8,76,96,186]. Therefore, to maximize the performance of packed bed reactors, finding an optimal balance between flow velocity and particle size is necessary. This will minimize the boundary layer thickness without compromising flow uniformity or bed residence time. 4.1 Packed-bed reactor configurations The search for greater efficiency in mass transfer in enzyme-catalyzed processes has resulted in changes in the configurations of packed-bed reactors, such as microreactors, milli reactors, and rotating packed-bed reactors [108,109,112,210]. Fig. 5 illustrates the configurations of these reactors. Micro (internal diameter ≤ 1 mm) or millifluidic (internal diameter between 1 and 5 mm) packed-bed reactors are a promising alternative to conventional beds due to their easy reproducibility, high surface-to-volume ratio, safety, process control, and scalability [39,112,190,211]. They have been investigated for the most diverse reactions. Reactors with such a small internal diameter have intensified mass and heat transfer processes, mainly due to rapid mixing based on molecular diffusion, the absence of concentration gradients, and a Reynolds number lower than 100, allowing the reaction conditions to be more easily controlled [39,191]. Therefore, due to the low restrictions on mass transfer, the kinetics established by microreactors are close to those intrinsic to the reaction [39] and, in addition, favor the design arrangement for complex reactions that occur in cascades, allowing the compartmentalization of reactions [111]. Gómez-Meyer et al. [190] reported comparing a millireactor and a microreactor, both with a packed-bed, to improve the operational stability of the commercial enzyme catalyst Novozym 435® during the oxidation of 2,5-furandicarboxaldehyde. On a micro-scale, the reaction yield was 20 % higher compared to the same reaction carried out in a packed-bed millireactor, reaching productivity 1000 times greater. The maximum specific productivity was reached at the highest flow rate evaluated (36 µL min-1), with the authors justifying that the shorter residence time allowed less contact of the catalyst with inactivating compounds in the reaction. In continuous mode, both reactors showed low operational stability. After 24 h of operation, the conversion yield was 0 % for the millireactor and only 7 % for the microreactor. Another configuration that stands out is the rotating packed-bed reactor, also called a basket reactor [212]. This reactor uses centrifugal acceleration to enhance mass transfer, allowing reactants to mix and percolate through the bed of heterogeneous biocatalysts packed in a cylindrical basket [107,130]. Due to the action of the rotor, the liquid that permeates the packed-bed undergoes fragmentation, becoming thin liquid films, filaments, and droplets. As a result, the mass transfer coefficient between the liquid phase and the catalytic solid is one or two orders of magnitude greater than in a longitudinal flow packed-bed column [108,213]. Due to better mass transfer, this reactor configuration has attracted the interest of several researchers for heterogeneous enzymatic catalysis, especially for processes catalyzed by lipase [34,107–109,130,152,213,214]. The rotating bed achieves equivalent levels of conversion in significantly smaller volumes, reducing construction costs and being advantageous, mainly in processing units that have limited space, such as, for example, offshore units. However, as it is a rotating equipment, it requires a significantly greater energy input when compared to the longitudinal flow bed [107,215]. Therefore, a careful assessment must consider all aspects of the process, energy flows, and economic balance [107]. Aiming at the technical adequacy of this reactor configuration, researchers have sought to innovate in the structure of rotors, the efficiency of the mesh that wraps the packaging, the way the liquid is distributed, and enzyme immobilization strategies that make them more resistant to shear forces [34,213]. 2-Ethylhexyl palmitate ester (2-EHP) is an important industry input, having wide application in the production of food and cosmetics. However, its production through heterogeneous enzymatic catalysis is affected by its high viscosity, resulting in restrictions on mass transfer [152]. Xu et al. [152] investigated using a rotating packed-bed reactor for lipase-catalyzed 2-EHP production as a solution to mass transfer constraints, comparing the results to those of a CSTR. A higher gravity factor (β), defined as the ratio of centrifugal to gravitational force in the rotating bed, resulted in a 99.54 % conversion after one hour of reaction. This performance was significantly better than the 70.37 % yield achieved by a CSTR in 3 h, demonstrating the process improvement. However, substrate conversion suffered a negative influence after β greater than 15 and liquid flow above 100 mL min-1, these being the parameters that provided better mass transfer and adequate contact time. The rotating bed also provided a more favorable environment for maintaining the physical structure of the enzymatic catalyst because, under optimal process conditions, it could achieve 15 reaction batches until the conversion was less than 80 %, greater than 99 % during the first nine batches. On the other hand, the CSTR achieved less than 50 % after nine reaction batches. 4.2 Packed-bed reactor enhancement tools In addition to changes in the reactor design, the addition of elements in the project has been explored as a tool to achieve better responses in mass transfer and substrate conversion, such as ultrasonic irradiation and supercritical fluids [33,69,70,143,172,194,216–220]. The intensification of enzyme-catalyzed processes with ultrasonic irradiation has been widely investigated. Generally, it occurs with the application of ultrasonic wave energy with frequencies between 10 and 100 kHz, resulting in cavitation [69,221]. Cavitation acts in microenvironments and is responsible for the local increase in temperature, creating free radicals in polar substrates or water, in addition to causing the action of shear forces and microflow caused by shock waves and implosion [69]. The effect of cavitation implies a decrease in the size of substrate particles, causing more efficient mixing and increasing the interface area between the substrate and the enzyme, resulting in a reduction in resistance to mass transfer and increasing the rate of enzymatic reactions in the special effect of lipases, with the activation effect of changing their conformation being reported [69,217,222]. Ultrasonic irradiation was applied in the continuous production of ethyl esters of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) in a solvent-free system [194]. To do this, they used a packed-bed reactor with the commercial immobilized lipase catalyst Novozym® 435 and immersed it in an ultrasonic bath operated at 37 kHz. The application of ultrasound proved effective in improving the external mass transfer coefficient and substrate access to the catalyst, resulting in an approximate conversion rate of 99 % at a flow rate of 1 mL min-1 and DHA + EPA concentration of 100 mM when evaluating the batch mode reactor configuration. However, under the same conditions, the reactor without the action of ultrasound achieved a conversion of approximately 98 %. Although the authors discuss the evolution as a significant increase, energy expenditure and benefits must be considered. On the other hand, at a flow rate of 5 mL min-1 and DHA + EPA concentration of 500 mM, the gains were more significant, increasing substrate conversion from 87 % to 93 % when comparing packed-bed reactors with and without ultrasonic irradiation. The catalyst remained stable for 120 h when tested under maximum conversion conditions in both reactors [194]. Supercritical fluids have been reported as a method of intensifying enzymatic processes. They present advantages such as low viscosity and high diffusivity, improving mass transfer in enzyme-catalyzed systems [68,223,224]. The supercritical state of a substance is reached when the supercritical temperature and pressure are exceeded, allowing the properties of the fluid to transition between those of a liquid and those of a gas [68,224]. The low viscosity of supercritical fluids (close to that of gases) favors the mass transfer of the system, combined with the adjustable density that allows controlling the solubility of solutes, making it a versatile solvent [68,224,225]. Carbon dioxide is the fluid most used in the application of supercritical technology due to its low cost, inertness, non-toxic or flammable nature, and full recovery is possible, significantly reducing the need for organic solvents [33,68,224,226]. Due to its moderate critical properties (Pc = 7.38 MPa and Tc = 31.05 °C), supercritical CO2 has been widely used in enzymatic catalysis as it does not offer pressure and temperature capable of damaging the enzyme [33,68,224,226–228]. The continuous synthesis of isoamyl acetate esters under supercritical CO2 was carried out in a packed-bed reactor with the Novozym® 435 catalyst, and the mass transfer mechanisms of the enzymatic reactions were discussed [33]. The maximum conversion of isoamyl acetate (96.7 %) was achieved for the lowest substrate feed flow rate evaluated (0.2 mL min-1), with a supercritical CO2 flow rate of 0.4 L min-1 at 40 °C. According to the authors, the longer residence time it resulted in a reduction in mass transfer limitations, providing a greater opportunity for interaction between the substrate and the active site of the lipase. The stability of the catalyst to the process was evaluated by repeating the optimal conditions found during 6 h of continuous reaction, maintaining the conversion above 92 %. The model developed for mass transfer proved to be effective in predicting the conversion and concentration of products, containing two adjustable parameters (reaction rate constant and partition coefficient). Furthermore, the sensitivity analysis indicates that the isoamyl acetate outlet concentration increased markedly with the increase in the inlet molar ratio of fusel oil to acetic anhydride, reaching a maximum of 1. The length-to-diameter ratio did not significantly alter reactor performance for small or high reaction times, with all curves converging at a point at the reaction time of approximately 5.5 h [33]. 5 Future perspectives Packed-bed reactors (PBR) have gained prominence in lipase-catalyzed reactions due to their ability to accommodate large volumes of heterogeneous catalysts in compact spaces. This configuration enhances enzyme loading, reaction rates, and stability by minimizing shear forces that could otherwise compromise the structural integrity of immobilized enzymes. As a result, these systems enable extended catalyst lifespans and reduced production costs. However, the evaluation of reactor productivity, a parameter that correlates product formation, reaction time, and catalyst usage, remains underexplored in the literature. Most studies rely on conversion rates, which limit discussions about the overall quality and efficiency of the processes employed. A shift toward standardized evaluations, particularly those emphasizing space-time yield, would allow a more comprehensive analysis of mass transfer limitations. These limitations remain a significant challenge in heterogeneous catalysis within PBR, particularly at an industrial scale. Addressing these issues is crucial, as mass transfer affects both the efficiency and scalability of enzymatic processes. Socio-environmental demands drive interest in green, sustainable, and economically viable approaches, including solvent-free processes that reduce environmental impact. Technological advancements have introduced novel approaches to address these challenges. Innovations in support materials have focused on improving mass transfer efficiency, with developments such as hydrophilic coatings, advanced polymer matrices, and supports with hierarchical pore structures. These materials enhance substrate-enzyme interactions while minimizing diffusional restrictions. In the future, some trends will be up-and-coming. Integrating 3D printing technologies will enable the manufacture of customized supports and reactors with optimized designs for specific applications. In addition, genetic engineering of enzymes can increase catalytic stability under adverse conditions, such as high temperatures and organic solvents, expanding the use of these systems in different industrial sectors. Additionally, integrating ultrasonic irradiation and supercritical CO2 technologies offers innovative pathways to intensify mass transfer and reaction kinetics in PBR. These techniques are particularly beneficial for solvent-free systems, enabling high mass transfer rates while reducing the environmental footprint. Despite their potential, further research is required to validate their economic feasibility and environmental sustainability through life cycle assessments. Technological reactor innovations focus on optimizing hydrodynamic performance and controlling operational parameters. Reactors designed with advanced geometries seek to minimize problems such as channeling and dead zones. At the same time, integrated sensors allow real-time monitoring of critical variables such as temperature, pH, and reagent concentration. Automation and modular systems have made packed bed reactors more flexible, allowing rapid adaptation to different industrial applications. The design of PBR themselves is also evolving. Rotating packed-bed reactors (RPBR), for example, demonstrate improved mass transfer characteristics due to the high centrifugal forces applied. Developing energy-efficient rotors for RPBR could optimize these systems, making them cost-competitive with traditional longitudinal-flow PBR. Moreover, structured packings and microreactors are being explored to enhance mixing and reduce mass transfer resistances. Lastly, while much attention is given to improving enzymatic performance and process efficiency, the environmental impact of catalyst production and disposal must not be overlooked. Integrating these technologies into circular economy models is essential. This involves prioritizing reusable and recyclable support materials and ensuring that waste is minimized or properly managed. The future of packed-bed reactors in enzymatic catalysis is promising, with ongoing advancements in support materials, reactor design, and process intensification technologies. These developments, coupled with a commitment to sustainability and economic feasibility, have the potential to position PBR as a foundational technology in green chemistry and industrial biotechnology. 6 Conclusion This review article provided and discussed important elements that impact the use of immobilized lipase catalysts in packed-bed reactors, pointing out the advantages and disadvantages of using some of the most used commercial catalysts and innovations proposed by authors in the last five years in addition to discussing characteristics of the equipment and elements used to intensify the catalytic process. It is believed that it could significantly contribute to advancing research into lipase-catalyzed reactions. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous immobilized lipase catalysts have been widely used in packed-bed reactors (PBR) in industry. This reactor configuration provides an environment with low shear forces, allows the catalyst to be easily recovered and reused, and continuously removes products and substrates not consumed by the reaction. This reduces inhibition of enzymatic activity and enables greater operational stability. This review aims to conduct a technical-scientific evaluation of the use of PBR with immobilized lipase catalysts. Therefore, the state-of-the-art was conducted by selecting articles published between 2019 and 2024. They were analyzed and discussed innovatively, focusing not only on the production methodologies of these enzymatic catalysts but also on the characteristics that make them suitable for the flow reactor, immobilization methods, reactor configurations, operational limitations, and process intensification techniques. The use of immobilized lipase catalysts in PBR is mainly limited by external mass transfer phenomena, which are among the most important topics discussed. This review could significantly contribute to advancing research into reactions catalyzed by lipases.
coredata.dc:title: Innovations in packed-bed reactors utilizing immobilized lipase catalysts: A comprehensive technical and scientific review
